facts.text: Petition No. 683 of 1951 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORGINAL JURISDICTION. Petition  No. 683 of 1951  under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner detained in Baroda Central Prison.

anchor.surface_text: habeas companypus and for the immediate release of the petitioner who is alleged to have been kept in illegal detention in Baroda Central Prison.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on February 15, 1951 under detention order dated February 13, 1951 by District Magistrate, Surat under Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On February 15, 1951, the petitioner was arrested under an order made on February 13, 1951, by the then District Magistrate, Surat, in exercise of powers companyferred on him by the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

facts.text: Copy of detention order served on petitioner at time of arrest.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of the said order was served on the petitioner at the time of his ar- rest.

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on petitioner on February 15, 1951 as required by section 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date grounds of detention were served on the petitioner as required by section 7 of the Act.

facts.text: Grounds mentioned it was in public interest not to disclose further facts.

anchor.surface_text: It was specifically mentioned in the grounds that it was number in the public interest to disclose further facts.

facts.text: Petitioner filed application in Bombay High Court under Article 226 claiming detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner moved the High Court of Bombay under article 226 of the Constitution companyplaining that his detention was illegal and praying that he should be forthwith released.

facts.text: Petitioner urged in High Court that grounds were false, vague, fantastic and detention in bad faith.

anchor.surface_text: In that appli- cation one of the points urged was that the grounds in support of the detention were false, vague and fantastic and that the detention order was made in bad faith.

facts.text: Two affidavits filed by State in High Court in support of detention order.

anchor.surface_text: Two affida- vits were filed on behalf of the State in support of the detention order.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed petitioner's application on April 17, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: That application was, on April 17, 1951, dismissed by the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Advisory Board made report on April 5, 1951 stating sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board which on Aprils, 1951, made a report stating that in its opinion there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: Government decided to confirm detention order on April 13, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: According to the affidavit of Venilal Tribho- vandas Dehejia, Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department, filed in answer to the present application, this report of the Advisory Board was placed before the Govern- ment and, on April 13, 1951, the Government decided to companyfirm the order of detention.

facts.text: Confirmation communicated to District Magistrate, Surat on April 28, 1951 via confidential letter.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was, on April 28, 1951, companymunicated to the District Magistrate, Surat, in a companyfidential letter in the terms following --

facts.text: Letter signed by G. K. Kharkar for Secretary to Government of Bombay, Home Department.

anchor.surface_text: Sd -G, K. Kharkar, for Secretary to the Government of Bom- bay, Home Department.

facts.text: G. K. Kharkar was Assistant Secretary authorized under rule 12 of Rules of Business under Article 166.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears from the aforesaid affidavit that Sri K. Kharkar who signed the letter for the Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department, was at the time an Assistant Secretary and, as such, was, under rule 12 of the Rules of Business made by the Government of Bombay under article 166 of the Constitution, authorised to sign orders and instruments of the Government of Bombay.

facts.text: Petitioner filed petition in Supreme Court under Article 32 claiming unlawful detention.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has number moved this Court under article 32 of the Constitution companyplaining that he is being unlawfully detained.

facts.text: Supplementary petition filed complaining grounds false, vague, lacking particulars.

anchor.surface_text: Although a supplementary petition has been filed in this Court companyplaining that the grounds supplied to him are false, vague, lacking in particulars and insufficient to enable the petitioner to make an effective representation against the order of detention,

facts.text: Supplementary petition not pressed before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: it has number, however, been pressed before us by learned companynsel appearing as amicus curiae in support of the application.

facts.text: Petitioner challenged detention on ground that confirmation order omitted to specify period under section 11(1).

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing before us, learned companynsel has companyfined his arguments to challeng- ing the validity of detention of the petitioner on two grounds, namely,  1  that the State Government has failed to companyply with the requirements of section 11 1  of the amended Act in that at the time of companyfirming the detention order it omitted to specify the period during which the detention would companytinue,

issues.text: Whether the State Government failed to comply with section 11(1) of the Preventive Detention Act by omitting to specify the period of detention continuation in the confirmation order, thereby invalidating the detention?

anchor.surface_text: that the State Government has failed to comply with the requirements of section 11 1  of the amended Act in that at the time of confirming the detention order it omitted to specify the period during which the detention would continue,

issues.text: Whether the confirmation order is invalid for not being in proper legal form, specifically not expressed in the name of the Governor as required by Article 166(1) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that the order of confirmation is not in proper legal form, in that it is not expressed to be made in the name of the Governor as required by article 166  1  of -the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner has been deprived of personal liberty without following the procedure established by law under the Preventive Detention Act?

anchor.surface_text: The only question is whether he has been deprived of his personal liberty in accordance with procedure estab- lished by law.

issues.text: Whether Article 166(1) of the Constitution is mandatory or merely directory with respect to the form of executive action like the detention confirmation order?

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of that article, like their counterpart in the Government of India Act, are merely directory and not mandatory

arguments.claim: State Government failed to comply with section 11(1) of the Preventive Detention Act by omitting to specify the period of detention in the confirmation order, invalidating the detention

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing before us, learned counsel has confined his arguments to challenging the validity of detention of the petitioner on two grounds, namely, 1 that the State Government has failed to comply with the requirements of section 11(1) of the amended Act in that at the time of confirming the detention order it omitted to specify the period during which the detention would continue,

arguments.court_reasoning: Grammatical analysis shows separate powers to confirm and continue; continuation automatic upon confirmation; temporary nature of Act limits duration; precedents like Gopalan support no indefinite detention issue

arguments.claim: Confirmation order invalid as not expressed in the name of the Governor as required by Article 166(1)

anchor.surface_text: and 2 that the order of confirmation is not in proper legal form, in that it is not expressed to be made in the name of the Governor as required by article 166(1) of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: directs his subordinate to act or forbear from acting in a particular way, but when the executive decision affects an outsider or is required to be o

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 166 directory not mandatory; omission removes presumption of Governor's authority but does not invalidate if decision proven; precedents like JK Gas Plant

arguments.claim: Section 11(1) requires only executive decision to confirm detention; no need to specify period as detention continues automatically

anchor.surface_text: Learned Attorney-General urges that section 11(1) of the Act contemplates only the taking of an executive decision, namely. the confirmation of the detention order and contends that the sub-section does not contemplate the making of a formal order.

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted by Das J. via grammatical parsing and automatic continuation logic

arguments.claim: No formal order required under s11(1); distinction from s3; like s13 implies decision suffices

arguments.court_reasoning: Decision required but form not prescribed by Act; Art166 supplies directory form

arguments.claim: Article 166 provisions are directory not mandatory; omission does not invalidate

anchor.surface_text: Learned Attorney-General then falls back upon the plea that an omission to make and authenticate an executive decision in the form mentioned in article 166 does not make the decision itself illegal, for the provisions of that article... are merely directory and not mandatory

court_response_anchor.surface_text: detention is made is worded differently in this respect and it merely empowers the Central Government.or the State Government, as the case may be, to

arguments.court_reasoning: Well settled directory for public duties; no inconvenience promotion; JK Gas precedent

arguments.claim: s11(1) grammatically confers two powers: confirm and continue separately; no need to specify period in confirmation

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 1. The validity of this ground of attack depends on a proper understanding of section 11(1)... Grammatically section 11(1) confers two powers, namely 1 the appropriate Government may confirm the detention order and 2 the appropriate Government may continue the detention

arguments.qualifiers: I do not think this argument is sound

arguments.claim: Specification of period not required as detention continues automatically post-confirmation; no two constructions possible

anchor.surface_text: The confirmation of the detention order certainly contemplates the taking of an. executive decision, but the detenu being already in custody and the detention order being confirmed his detention continues automatically and, therefore, nofurther executive decision

arguments.claim: Temporary Act limits any indefinite detention; precedents (Gopalan, Krishnan) confirm

anchor.surface_text: Further, the notion that nospecification of the period will continue the detention for an indefinite period need not oppress us unduly, because the Act itself being of a limited duration such detention must necessarily come to an end

arguments.claim: s11(1) requires decision on period but omission not nullity in temporary Act; implies till expiry

anchor.surface_text: The point is not free from doubt, but having regard to the fact that the new Preventive Detention Act is a temporary statute... I am inclined to hold that nospecification of the further period... does not make the order of detention a nullity

arguments.qualifiers: not free from doubt; inclined to hold

arguments.claim: Art166(1) directory; applies to formal expression but omission loses immunity not validity

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, article 166 of the Constitution which purports to lay down the procedure... should be read as a whole... non-compliance... would lead to this result that the order in question would lose the protection

arguments.claim: s11(1) obliges specification of period; words 'such period as it thinks fit' require fixing duration

anchor.surface_text: The words such period as it thinks fit have the meaning that government has to specify and fix the period of such detention... Such a construction, to my mind, has to be avoided unless the language employed conclusively points to it

arguments.court_reasoning: Minority view; majority holds no requirement

arguments.claim: Failure to specify period prejudicial and makes detention illegal

anchor.surface_text: After considerable thought I have reached the conclusion that the non-determination by Government of the period of the continuance of the detention operates prejudicially against the detenus and makes the detention illegal

arguments.claim: Grounds of detention false, vague, fantastic; bad faith

anchor.surface_text: In that application one of the points urged was that the grounds in support of the detention were false, vague and fantastic and that the detention order was made in bad faith.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , for if the intention were that both the things should be included in an order then the sub-section would have been worded differently. It would have

holdings.text: On a proper construction of section 11(1), a specification of the period of continuation of the detention is not necessary, however desirable one may consider it to be.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment, on a proper construction of section 11(1), a specification of the period of continuation of the detention is not necessary, however desirable one may consider it to be.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grammatical construction separates confirmation and continuation powers; detention continues automatically upon confirmation; temporary nature of Act prevents indefinite detention; precedents like Gopalan and Krishnan confirm.

holdings.text: The provisions of article 166... are merely directory and not mandatory; omission to comply does not render the executive action a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, this contention of the learned Attorney-General must prevail. It is well settled that generally speaking the provisions of a statute creating public duties are directory and those conferring private rights are imperative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions create public duties; strict compliance causes inconvenience without promoting object; loses presumption/immunity but validity proven by affidavit of decision and authorization.

holdings.text: There has been, in the circumstances of this case, no breach of the procedure established by law and the present detention of the petitioner cannot be called in question.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, all that the procedure established by law requires is that the appropriate Government must take a decision as to whether the detention order should be confirmed or not under section 11(1). That such a decision has been in fact taken by the appropriate Government is amply proved on the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executive decision to confirm taken on April 13, 1951, communicated April 28; signer authorized; complies with Act despite Art 166 omission.

holdings.text: Article 166 of the Constitution which purports to lay down the procedure... should be read as a whole... non-compliance... would lead to this result that the order in question would lose the protection.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, article 166 of the Constitution which purports to lay down the procedure for regulating business transacted by the Government of a State should be read as a whole.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses 1 and 2 read together provide immunity upon compliance; omission removes immunity but does not invalidate if authority proven; Federal Court precedent in JK Gas Plant.

holdings.text: No-specification of the further period in an order under section 11(1) of the Act does not make the order of detention a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: The point is not free from doubt, but having regard to the fact that the new Preventive Detention Act is a temporary statute... I am inclined to hold that no-specification of the further period... does not make the order of detention a nullity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary statute implies continuation till expiry; no prejudice as review expected under s13; desirable but omission not fatal.

holdings.text: The non-determination by Government of the period of the continuance of the detention operates prejudicially against the detenus and makes the detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: After considerable thought I have reached the conclusion that the non-determination by Government of the period of the continuance of the detention operates prejudicially against the detenus and makes the detention illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'such period as it thinks fit' require fixing duration; failure discharges onus on authority; indefinite repugnant.

precedents.citation: Petition No. 308 of 1951  Makha, Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: Petition No. 308 of 1951  Makha, Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab , it is illegal, after the amendment of the Act, to mention any period of detention in the initial order of detention made under section 3 of the Act and if numberperiod of detention need be mentioned at the time of companyfirmation under section 11  1  then the appropriate Government will, after companyfirmation, lose sight of the case and the detenu will be detained indefinitely.

precedents.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: illegal to mention any period of detention in the initial order under section 3 after amendment
precedents.cited_holding: it is illegal, after the amendment of the Act, to mention any period of detention in the initial order of detention made under section 3

anchor.surface_text: In A.K. Gopalans case 1 , Kania J. at page 126 said-- It was argued that section 11 of the impugned Act was invalid as it permitted the companytinuance of the detention for such period as the Central Government or the State Govern- ment thought fit. This may mean an indefinite period. In my opinion, this argument has numbersubstance because the Act has to be read as a whole. The whole life of the Act is for a year and therefore the argument that the detention may be for an indefinite period is unsound.

precedents.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: section 11 permits detention for indefinite period but valid because Act is temporary
precedents.cited_holding: the detention may be for an indefinite period is unsound because the Act has to be read as a whole and is for a year

precedents.citation: S. Krishnan v. The State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: indeed in S. Krishnan v. The State of Madras 1  Sastri J., aS he then was, expressed himself as follows in companynection with the present section 11  1 - The objection to the validity of section 11  1  can be disposed of in a few words. The argument is that the dis- cretionary power given to the appropriate Government under that sub-section to companytinue the detention for such period as it thinks fit authorises preventive detention for an indefinite period, which is companytrary to the provisions of article 22.  4 . But, if as already observed, the new Act is to be in force only up to 1st April, 1952, and numberdetention under the Act can companytinue thereafter, the discretionary power companyld be exercised only subject to that over-all limit.

precedents.case_name: S. Krishnan v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: section 11(1) valid as detention limited by life of temporary Act
precedents.cited_holding: discretionary power to continue detention subject to over-all limit of Act's duration

precedents.citation: Petition No. 584 of 1951, Chakar Singh v. The State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: This view of the matter will, however, run companynter to our decision in Petition No. 584 of 1951, Chakar Singh v. The State of Punjab, where it has been held that there is numberhing in section 11  1  to prevent the appropri- ate Government from directing the detention of a person to companytinue further so long as the period fixed by the previ- ous order has number expired and the person has number been released.

precedents.case_name: Chakar Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: government can extend detention before expiry of previous period under section 11(1)
precedents.cited_holding: nothing in section 11(1) prevents directing further continuance before previous period expires

Gas Plant Manufacturing Co.  Rampur  Ltd. and Others v. The King-Emperor 1 .

Gas Plant Manufacturing Company Limited and Others King-Emperor 1 , where a somewhat analogous provision companytained in section 49 1  of Schedule IX of the Government of India Act came up for companysideration and the provision was held to be directory and number imperative.

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this Court in Makkan Singh Tarsikha State of Punjab, Petition No. 308 of 1951, that fixing of the period of detention in the initial order of detention under section 3 is companytrary to the scheme of the Act

precedents.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: fixing period in initial order contrary to scheme of Act
precedents.cited_holding: fixing of the period of detention in the initial order of detention under section 3 is contrary to the scheme of the Act

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by me in Gopalans case 1 , the law of  1  1950 S.C.R, 88. 88 preventive detention during peace times is an evil of neces- sity as it deprives a person of his personal liberty without a trial and even without a personal hearing and that being so, the safeguards provided against unregulated executive action have to be companystrued as widely as possible for the benefit of the person detained.

precedents.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: preventive detention law to be construed in favour of detenu

precedents.citation: Chakkar Singh v. The State of Punjab  Petition No. 584 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this Court in Chakkar Singh v. The State of Punjab  Petition No. 584 of 1951 , that the power of the detaining authority under section 11 is number exhausted once it specifies the period of detention but that it can, before the expiration of the period initially fixed, direct the detention of a person to companytinue for a further period

precedents.case_name: Chakar Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: power under s.11 not exhausted after specifying period; can extend before expiry
precedents.cited_holding: power not exhausted; can direct further continuance

precedents.citation: Prahlad Krishna v. The State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed by the learned Attorney-General in support of his companytention on two decisions of the High Courts in India. In Prahlad Krishna v. The State of Bombay 1 , it was held that it was number necessary to men- tion the period during which the detenu will be further detained after the State Government had companyfirmed the deten- tion order.

precedents.case_name: Prahlad Krishna v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: no necessity to mention period in confirmation order
precedents.cited_holding: not necessary to mention the period during which the detenu will be further detained after confirmation

precedents.citation: Ram Adhar Misra v. The State 1

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Adhar Misra v. The State 1 , it was held that an order of detention which does number specify the period of detention cannot be regarded as illegal. Reliance was placed on the observations of the late Chief Justice and myself in Gopalans case 2 , and cited earlier in this judgment.

precedents.cited_proposition: order without specified period not illegal
precedents.cited_holding: an order of detention which does not specify the period of detention cannot be regarded as illegal

anchor.surface_text: The result is that both the grounds fail and the petition is dismissed. CHANDRASEKHARA AIYAR J.--I companycur in the order just number pronounced by my learned brother Mukherjea J. and I have numberhing useful to add.
